awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Mechanisms of tree population collapses in eastern North America:  Disentangling causes of abrupt ecological change during the Holocene
awd_abstract_narration:
Trees are dying at alarming rates worldwide, raising concerns about forest health in the face of increasing droughts and fires. In the US, eastern forests have been less affected by droughts and fires than western forests. However, several eastern tree species -- notably eastern hemlock and American beech -- have experienced big population collapses over the last several thousand years.  Hence, eastern forests may be at greater risk of collapse than commonly thought.  This project will collect new data and apply powerful mathematical tools to test hypotheses about why hemlock and beech forests have suffered big declines. Researchers will focus on the roles of severe droughts, bigger and more frequent fires, and greater competition among tree species.  Ultimately, this project seeks to 1) better understand the fundamental processes that trigger abrupt collapse of tree populations and 2) thereby inform and reduce current risks to forest health.

The project will analyze long-term records (>6,000 years, at decadal resolution) of forest composition, fire regime, and drought, based on lake sediment cores to be collected at four sites -- two at places where beech and hemlock are abundant today and two where only beech is abundant.  At each site, the timing of past tree population declines will be established by records of fossil pollen and radiocarbon dates, while past fire events will be identified through analysis of the abundance of charcoal fragments in sediments.  Because plant water stress affects the kinds of carbon isotopes in plant tissue, this project will identify past drought episodes through an innovative approach that requires precise measurements of the carbon isotopic content of individual pollen grains.  Because all records will be co-located from the same sediment cores, the relative sequence of events will be precisely known.  At two sites, reconstructions of changes in lake water balance, based on characteristics of the lake sediments, will provide an independent check on the drought and water-stress signals inferred from carbon isotopes.  A new community-level statistical model will integrate data and be used to test hypotheses about the relative importance of drought, fire events, and competition on past declines of tree populations.  All data collected will be archived in the Neotoma Paleoecology Database, an open public repository of long ecological records, curated by experts.  All source code for statistical software developed here will be made publicly available, and a workshop will be held to train students and early career scientists in the new methods that will be developed.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Aridification and increasing hydroclimate variability are increasing the likelihood of ecosystem transformations in the US and worldwide, either directly through drought stress or indirectly through shifting fire regimes. Most attention has focused on the vulnerability of semi-arid forests in the western US, with less attention to the wetter forests of the east. However, water-sensitive tree taxa in this region have experienced multiple large and often abrupt abundance declines during the warm climates of the past 11,000 years, particularly for the late-successional taxa eastern hemlock (Tsuga canadensis) and American beech (Fagus grandifolia), and causes remain unclear.  To better understand the long-term patterns and drivers of compositional changes in mesic forests in the eastern United States during the Holocene (the last ~11,500 years), this project (1) collected a series of new long-term records of past climate, vegetation, and fire history from lake sedimentary archives in the Great Lakes region, (2) developed a new time-series modeling approach, called multinomialTS, to test hypotheses about the relative importance of climatic drivers and species interactions on forest community dynamics, and (3) integrated these datasets and models with each other and other long-term records of forest community dynamics from the Neotoma Paleoecology Database.

Key findings include: (1) Centennial-to-millennial scale changes occurred in the steepness of the north-south temperature gradient during the Holocene, which likely drove other changes in rainfall patterns and forest composition. (2) Large variations in moisture availability, including persistent multimillennial droughts, occurred during the Holocene in the areas of tree populations of collapses. (3) The climate of the present day and historical record have been generally wet compared to the rest of the Holocene. (4) The large past changes in forest composition can be linked to changes in temperature, aridity, and fire regime. (5) In at least some regions of the US, sites that are closer to major vegetation ecotones show a higher sensitivity to past climate variability than more distant locations. (6) Forest ecosystems in the eastern United States have been highly sensitive to past climate changes, which reinforces concerns about their sensitivity to anthropogenic global warming.  

The project contributed to the education and training of one postdoctoral scientist, five graduate students (including three M.S. students and two Ph.D. students) and 13 undergraduate students (including three that participated in Research Experience for Undergraduates [REU] programs). The project also contributed to diversifying the scientific workforce and supporting America’s veterans by supporting eight women and three students who are veterans of the U.S. Air Force and U.S. Army. The project also trained over 50 scientists, most of whom were early-career scientists, in advanced time-series modeling of ecological datasets during a workshop held at the annual meeting of the Ecological Society of America.  

All findings have been published in leading peer-reviewed journals, with several articles published and more on the way.  All physical samples, data, and code have been made publicly available or will be upon publication.  The project: (1) has archived (at the Continental Scientific Drilling facility at the University of Minnesota Twin Cities) the new sediment cores that it obtained from Story Lake in Indiana and Sunrise Lake and Lake Lavine in Michigan; (2) has archived paleoecological and paleoclimatic data from these sites in the Neotoma Paleoecology Database, (3) designed and publicly shared on GitHub a freely-available R package multinomialTS for statistical modeling of community time-series data to allow testing of hypotheses about the relative importance of external drivers of community dynamics and biotic interactions.
